report_title: Horse & Other Equine Production in the US
executive_summary:
The strong economy in the years preceding the pandemic led to record-low unemployment and surging wages. These conditions caused consumer confidence to skyrocket, so people were more willing to make risky investments in horse racing, which increased producers' revenue. During COVID-19, the federal government gave Americans massive amounts of aid. Consumers spent more on horses, which boosted revenue for producers.

Rising interest rates have fostered recessionary fears, as a higher cost of borrowing has the potential to bring the economy to a halt. Recessionary fears have reduced consumer confidence, causing spending on horses for many equestrian activities to plunge. This has resulted in falling revenue in 2021 and 2022. COVID-19, disrupted supply chains and the appreciating dollar have caused exports to decline, reducing a significant revenue stream for horse and other equine producers. Overall, revenue for horse and other equine producers is anticipated to creep upward at a CAGR of 0.6% during the current period, reaching $1.8 billion in 2023. Revenue is anticipated to rise 2.0% in that same year.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue for horse and other equine producers is expected to creep upward at a CAGR of 0.6% during the current period, reaching $1.8 billion in 2023. Revenue is anticipated to climb 2.0% in 2023.

In the years before COVID-19, record-low unemployment caused wages to soar. As incomes rose, consumers spent more on horses for various purposes like racing and recreation, increasing industry revenue. The strong economy also kept consumer confidence high, so individuals invested more in horses.

COVID-19 led to social distancing that reduced demand from horse racing. However, federal government aid gave consumers funds to spend on horses for isolated activities like horseback riding, keeping revenue growth alive in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Inflation and Interest Rates Hurt Confidence
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: High inflation has caused the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, fostering recessionary fears that have reduced consumer confidence. Spending on risky investments like horses for racing and showing has declined, causing revenue to fall recently.
The pandemic disrupted supply chains and caused the US dollar to appreciate, reducing exports for horse and equine producers and hindering a significant revenue stream.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Revenue for horse and other equine producers is anticipated to rise at a CAGR of 0.5% during the outlook period, reaching $1.9 billion in 2028. Profit is forecast to comprise 18.2% of revenue in that year.

Stable economic growth will foster rising incomes and less volatility, raising consumer confidence. High confidence boosts spending on risky investments like horse racing, contributing to rising industry revenue.
As supply chains improve, feed prices will decline, reducing costs for horse farmers but also eliminating a revenue stream from passing on high input costs to buyers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Exports to Rise with Cheaper Dollar
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The US dollar is anticipated to depreciate, making domestically produced horses less expensive abroad. This will increase exports and revenue for horse producers.
Producers hope innovations like better horse feed, GPS tracking, and synthetic tracks will improve their products and make purchasing horses more attractive to the broader public, increasing revenue.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry raise horses, mules, donkeys and other equines (mammals belonging to the Equidae family) for transportation, racing events, rodeo competitions and other recreational sports. These establishments are commonly referred to as ranches, farms or studs.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - steady

key_trends: High incomes kept revenue rising during COVID-19
Falling consumer spending has posed a threat to horse and other equine producers

market_segmentation.segment_description: Horses are used on farms to help plow fields, move across large farms and assist in the moving of materials and crops when necessary.
Consumers buy horses for personal use to compete in racing and showing. Many also use them for horseback riding and other recreational purposes.

Horse and other equine producers sell horses to boarding facilities, for breeding purposes. They're also sold for training for equine-related sports. Horse boarding, breeding and training are necessary when equines compete in sports (e.g., horse racing), so spending from these segments has risen as spending on competitive sports has increased in the wake of the recovery from the pandemic.
Demand from other markets also surged, as these horses are primarily used for sports (e.g., rodeos, polo sports).
Horses purchased primarily for riding and recreational purposes.

products_and_services.product_description: Horses used for recreation are bought by consumers for recreational riding. Spending on other equines for transportation and other practical purposes is also included in this segment.

As incomes have increased because of government relief during the pandemic and rising wages, consumers have had more money to spend on horses, increasing this segment's revenue share during the current period.
Horses for show comprise more than one-fifth of the industry's revenue. Individuals buy these horses to compete in dressage, jumping and rodeo events.

Consumers purchase horses to use them to compete in racing activities. They also often buy Thoroughbreds that are used for breeding. Since individuals that compete in horse races are spending lots of money on the races and the horses, they're more willing to make these risky investments when their confidence in the economy's future is high. Racehorses' share of revenue has plunged during the current period, as consumer confidence has fallen because of COVID-19, high inflation and recessionary fears.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita disposable incomes are pivotal in determining participation in horse-related recreational activities. Horse ownership can be expensive because owners incur maintenance costs associated with stabling, feed, supplies, training and veterinary services. More per capita disposable income will make horse ownership more affordable and increase participation in racing events.

Demand for racehorses is primarily driven by activity in the downstream horse racing industry. An increase in horse racing will increase demand for racing Thoroughbreds. The prosperity of US racehorse production depends on the level of wagering at racetracks. The amount of prize money and incentive payments received by racehorse owners also determine the funds available for purchasing Thoroughbreds from studs.

Exports comprise a significant share of revenue and are driven mainly by the sale of horses for racing purposes, including Thoroughbred breeding. The dollar's value relative to the currencies of the United States' biggest trading partners, as indicated by the trade-weighted index (TWI), forms a part of export demand. As the TWI rises, the value of the dollar increases relative to the currency of foreign nations. As the TWI falls, US horses become more affordable to foreign buyers. Since high-performance racehorses are a high-value commodity, buyers are often undeterred by added expenses related to exchange rates and are more motivated by the pedigree of a horse. Exchange rates and the reputation of US-bred racehorses compared with horses from other countries help determine export demand.

Demand for horses for breeding and stocking purposes can depend on existing inventories, which may be affected by disease outbreaks. Reductions in the national equine population can push farmers to restock herds. Throughout the year, available supplies of horses are partly determined by the biological breeding cycle. Horses are seasonal breeders that typically produce small numbers of offspring each year.

Demand for other equines relies on demand from downstream users including riding schools, ranchers performing stock work, the police force and carriage services. Participation in equine-related recreational activities (e.g., trail riding) is a major factor driving demand for horses. Equestrian events such as dressage and show jumping also creates another source of demand.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The pandemic recovery has caused imports to soar. As mass vaccination caused the economy to open up, more people started attending horse racing competitions and other horse-related recreational events. More spending on these events has increased demand for competitive horses. Since Thoroughbreds and other competitive horses are bred abroad, imports have surged.

Ireland breeds some great horses. Equestrian sports are widespread and popular in Ireland. Breeds such as the Connemara pony and the Irish draught are bred with other horses to produce equines used for competitive sports. The quality of Ireland's horses has led the share of the industry's imports from that country to soar during the current period.

The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) has raised intake from Canada and Mexico. The USMCA was passed in 2020 and has made it easier to trade with Mexico and Canada. Since it has become easier to trade across North America, Mexico and Canada's share of the industry's exports has grown.

Equestrian activities have become more prevalent in Japan. As Japan has continuously adopted more elements of Western culture, equestrian activities have gained popularity. Since horses are rare in the country, demand for horses abroad has skyrocketed. Japan's share of exports has increased significantly during the current period.

The appreciating US dollar has made domestic horses more expensive. As the value of the US dollar has gone up, domestically bred horses have become more expensive to foreign buyers. Buyers have begun to get their equines from other countries, so exports have tumbled in recent years.

business_locations.location_description: Texas is home to more than one-third of all horse and equine producers. Horses need lots of land to roam and eat in, so companies want to find large farms to raise their breeds. Since Texas is the biggest state by land area, producers can find the farms they need there, giving the state so much prominence.

Horse racing, showing and other recreational activities using equines are common in the Southeast. One of these most popular events is the Kentucky Derby, which draws hundreds of thousands of people to the state every year. Since horse racing and other activities are a significant source of revenue for horse farmers, producers want to be located close to where these events take place, so there's a high penetration of establishments in this region.

The Plains region includes states such as Missouri, Iowa and Nebraska. These states have low population densities and good climates, so they're suitable for grain production. Since grain is a major stable in the diets of many horses, horse farmers want to be located near their farmers, so the industry has a significant presence in the Plains region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: There have been multiple moves to ban horse meat consumption in the United States. A ban was first enacted in 2007, but it expired in 2011. Recent presidents have proposed new bans in their budgets.
This law makes all horses for breeding eligible for federal emergency loans and disaster-relief funds and prohibits the commercial sale of wild burros.

This act expanded the monetary and criminal penalties for economic losses caused by acts of violence and damage toward farm animals. The law also broadened the scope of property and enterprises protected by the law.

Equine producers must follow state regulations that control the effects of agriculture on the local environment. These rules relate to the size of operations, waste disposal, odor control, animal health and water quality.
County zoning policies have a significant influence on start-up farms.

As the economy shut down, horse racing, showing and other recreational events were subject to social distancing and mask-wearing laws. This significantly reduced demand for these events, negatively impacting the industry.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The horse production industry is mature.
Capital intensity level is high for the industry.
Globalization level is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Price and quality are the two main factors for competition in the equine production industry.
Basic equine producers compete mainly on price, while specialist producers compete on quality and bloodlines.
The industry faces external competition from foreign producers based on factors like exchange rates and trade barriers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Since horses are used for competitive purposes, quality is more important than quantity, preventing major players from gaining economies of scale.
The lack of licensing requirements enables relatively easy entry, keeping the industry fragmented.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The price of feed is a vital determinant of the industry's success. When the price of feed is high, it becomes more expensive to give horses the necessary nutrition, so fewer consumers purchase them, damaging the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Horse and other equine producers have a high level of capital intensity. It's estimated that for every dollar spent on labor, the average horse and equine producer will spend $0.53 on capital goods and equipment.
Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Moderate ease and rate of entry
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Both the ease of entry and the rate of entry in the industry are moderate. While these factors do not significantly add to the threat of disruptive potential, they do not detract from it either.

Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: When incomes rise, consumers have more money to spend on horse racing, showing and other equine-related activities, so higher incomes boost revenue. Per capita disposable income rose during the recovery from the pandemic, growth for the industry. It has declined in recent years, as money given out by the government during COVID-19 has dried up. These fluctuations in disposable income have fostered increased volatility for horse producers in the United States.
The price of feed has fluctuated significantly during the current period because of weather events, supply chains and general economic conditions, which has raised revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Horse and other equine producers have displayed little disruption in recent years. Farmers run through legacy business models that cannot be easily mechanized. Many companies are also legacy businesses that have years of reputation and word-of-mouth credibility.

The Horse and Other Equine Production industry's adoption of increasingly sophisticated production methods coincides with microchip technology and computerized monitoring systems. Radio transponders or microchips inserted on a horse's neck between the ears and withers can be used to store details on birth and branding, veterinary treatments, weaning dates and ownership information. Software can also record and monitor horse health, performance and activities.

Increasing technological efficiencies is rooted in decreasing companies' cost per horse. The cost savings afforded to base equine producers through their adoption of advanced tagging technologies may still not necessarily be available to those establishments producing racing and show breeds.

FAQs.question: Were your sales particularly volatile during COVID-19?
FAQs.answer: Demand for horses tends to be most dependent on disposable income levels, as they are considered a luxury good. Consumers will slow the purchase of horses during tough economic times and increase purchases during favorable economic conditions. Racing revenue declined sharply because of disruption and postponement during the pandemic.

FAQs.question: How does your company hedge against price loss risk?
FAQs.answer: Diversified producers will exhibit lower degrees of revenue volatility, aiding profitability. By switching cropping activities, livestock farmers can plan what they wish to produce for the next foaling season. The LIP benefits livestock farmers when their animals die in excess because of adverse weather events or attacks by animals introduced into the wild by the Federal Government. The pandemic caused Congress to pass the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), which enabled companies to receive forgivable loans from the federal government to pay for lost wages and rents because of social distancing regulations and quarantines. Since horse racing, showing and other equine activities were severely restricted during COVID-19, horse farmers displayed plunging revenue. Many producers took advantage of PPP loans to recuperate these losses.

FAQs.question: In regard to unprecedented volatility in core-market activity, how does your company hedge against market risk?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term service contracts with customers will exhibit more stable revenue. Producers that exercise input-price and supply management will have a better time planning next year's foal crop, boosting potential profitability.

FAQs.question: With such volatile feed prices, how does your company manage volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Producers near key selling markets will display lower transportation costs and higher profitability. Producers that exercise input-price and supply management by entering into long-term purchase agreements will have a better time planning next year's foal crop, boosting potential profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company sought to use drone technology to monitor herds?
FAQs.answer: Operators leveraging the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiency and higher profitability. Artificial insemination technologies can enhance breeding efficiency and protect stallions. With the Federal Aviation Administration's legalization of commercial drone usage, monitoring herds has never been easier. Drones for commercial use present a wide array of applications and can save on labor costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via automation?
FAQs.answer: Labor costs can be reduced through the use of seasonal labor in conjunction with the latest technologies. This industry is capital-intensive but requires manual labor to tend to the horses.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant producers will display lower insurance premiums and costs, boosting profitability. Non-compliant producers will be subject to insurance cost increases, undercutting profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Shifting environmental regulations have the potential to increase operating costs for farmers. Electricity and fuel for heating barns are critical expenses, while horses also consume lots of water. These cost increases threaten profit.

FAQs.question: Has your company had any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have more stable revenue, enduring price declines better and protecting against volatility. Sometimes equine producers will produce at a loss, which is then made up for via government subsidies.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your biggest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Farmers that have a reputation for quality will be the most successful. Overall, racehorse lineages are highly sought after, and a farm with a strong reputation for producing winning studs will incur significantly higher revenue per sale.

FAQs.question: How does your company control for volatile input costs, such as that of feed?
FAQs.answer: Locating close to grain and hay sellers helps ensure a continuous supply of horse feed. Entering into long-term input purchase contracts from upstream suppliers will mitigate upside risk.

FAQs.question: How much of your production is devoted to premium products? Do you spend on marketing to position your products as top-quality?
FAQs.answer: Racehorses sell at a significant premium compared with workhorses and recreational horses. Winning racehorses can also be sold for a high premium to breed with other champions.

FAQs.question: Does your company situate itself between upstream and downstream core markets?
FAQs.answer: Locating close to key equine markets reduces transport costs and provides buyers easy access. Farms located closer to feed suppliers and end markets such as recreational consumers will perform better than those who are far-flung.

FAQs.question: Has your farm seen an increase in recreational sales?
FAQs.answer: Leisure time will dictate how much consumers spend on recreational horse activity.

FAQs.question: Was racehorse spending impacted by the postponement of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness during COVID-19?
FAQs.answer: Revenue trends in line with movements in betting activity and viewership of major race events.

FAQs.question: How was your company performed amid such an uncertain future?
FAQs.answer: Since horse races can be an expensive and risky investment, demand is particularly sensitive to consumer confidence.
